<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 123, 918, 142]]<|/det|>
2 Use logarithms to solve the equation \(4^{x+1}=5^{2 x-3}\), giving your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 185, 97, 202]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 187, 97, 202]]<|/det|>
3

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 197, 769, 378]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 398, 673, 415]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y=x-2 \ln x\) and its minimum point \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 429, 156, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 429, 382, 444]]<|/det|>
(i) Find the \(x\)-coordinate of \(M\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 460, 160, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 460, 690, 477]]<|/det|>
(ii) Use the trapezium rule with three intervals to estimate the value of

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 484, 568, 520]]<|/det|>
\[

\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 529, 537, 544]]<|/det|>
giving your answer correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 559, 163, 575]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 559, 920, 590]]<|/det|>
(iii) State, with a reason, whether the trapezium rule gives an under-estimate or an over-estimate of the true value of the integral in part (ii).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 618, 97, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 620, 568, 637]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[414, 644, 587, 682]]<|/det|>
\[
\int_{0}^{k} e^{4 x} d x=\int_{0}^{2 k} e^{x} d x
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 655, 920, 673]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 718, 97, 734]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 720, 156, 737]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 720, 650, 737]]<|/det|>
5 (i) By sketching a suitable pair of graphs, show that the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[458, 742, 543, 778]]<|/det|>
\[
\frac{1}{x}=\sin x
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[159, 782, 592, 803]]<|/det|>
where \(x\) is in radians, has only one root for \(0<x \leqslant \frac{1}{2} \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 816, 160, 833]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 816, 698, 832]]<|/det|>
(ii) Verify by calculation that this root lies between \(x=1.1\) and \(x=1.2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 853, 163, 870]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 845, 918, 894]]<|/det|>
(iii) Use the iterative formula \(x_{n+1}=\frac{1}{\sin x_{n}}\) to determine this root correct to 2 decimal places. Give the result of each iteration to 4 decimal places.

<｜end▁of▁sentence｜>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 76, 438, 95]]<|/det|>
6 The parametric equations of a curve are

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[378, 99, 620, 122]]<|/det|>
\[
x=1+2 \sin ^{2} \theta, \quad y=4 \tan \theta
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 147, 156, 164]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 138, 391, 173]]<|/det|>
(i) Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}=\frac{1}{\sin \theta \cos ^{3} \theta}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 186, 160, 203]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 183, 920, 220]]<|/det|>
(ii) Find the equation of the tangent to the curve at the point where \(\theta=\frac{1}{4} \pi\), giving your answer in the form \(y=m x+c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 246, 97, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 246, 920, 280]]<|/det|>
7 The polynomial \(a x^{3}-3 x^{2}-11 x+b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants, is denoted by \(\mathrm{p}(x)\). It is given that \((x+2)\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\), and that when \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divided by \((x+1)\) the remainder is 12 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 294, 156, 311]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 292, 374, 311]]<|/det|>
(i) Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 325, 160, 342]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 324, 631, 342]]<|/det|>
(ii) When \(a\) and \(b\) have these values, factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) completely.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 369, 97, 386]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 371, 156, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 371, 921, 403]]<|/det|>
8 (i) Express \(5 \cos \theta-3 \sin \theta\) in the form \(R \cos (\theta+\alpha)\), where \(R>0\) and \(0^{\circ}<\alpha<90^{\circ}\), giving the exact value of \(R\) and the value of \(\alpha\) correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 418, 160, 434]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 416, 363, 434]]<|/det|>
(ii) Hence solve the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[414, 435, 584, 456]]<|/det|>
\[
5 \cos \theta-3 \sin \theta=4
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 460, 545, 479]]<|/det|>
giving all solutions in the interval \(0^{\circ} \leqslant \theta \leqslant 360^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 492, 163, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 492, 627, 508]]<|/det|>
(iii) Write down the least value of \(15 \cos \theta-9 \sin \theta\) as \(\theta\) varies.

<｜end▁of▁sentence｜>
